title: Plastic pollution on course to double by 2030 | UN News
body: The UN Environment Programme (UNEP) warns that plastic waste in oceans and other bodies of water is a global problem that threatens health, the economy, biodiversity and the climate. It proposes solutions to reverse the crisis, such as reducing plastic production and consumption, shifting to circular approaches and investing in monitoring systems.
readable_content: - UN Website (2023-12-08): The UN Environment Programme has released an assessment highlighting the dire consequences of plastic pollution in oceans and bodies of water. The report emphasizes the need for drastic reduction in unnecessary plastic and proposes an accelerated transition to renewable energies and more circular approaches towards reduction. The assessment also addresses the limitations of recycling and the need for immediate reduction in plastic production and consumption. The report will inform discussions at the UN Environment Assembly in 2022, where countries will come together to decide a way forward for global cooperation.
summary:
The assessment released by the UN Environment Programme emphasizes the urgent need for drastic reduction in unnecessary plastic and a shift towards renewable energies and more circular approaches. This underlines the serious and urgent nature of the issue of plastic pollution. The report aims to inform discussions at the UN Environment Assembly for global cooperation.
